postsData.text:
Home made, snorkel based PAPR. Filter material is melt blown fabric (4+ layers). Runs on a drill battery. I specifically designed this NOT to use an off the shelf HEPA filter because they are flying off the shelves. I have 40M of melt blown fabric. Other materials could be wrapped around the filter cans, as supply dictates. It was fun to watch the design evolve, if I have time I am going to go back to square one and start over with my final concept in mind. I would also like to make a filter box that accepts 1 or 2 KN95 masks as the filter media. Let me know what you think.
P.s. the rubber bands were wayyy to long so that's why it looks kinda janky. Got the right size coming.
STEP file here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=1R-YBeJLVtvak6cK4vFvUA7WLjcVAVJ-T
Some parts may not be needed for your application.

postsData.text: I have an issue that I’m hoping some of you guys can help me with. I have a narrow nose and wear glasses, and every time I put on a dust mask my glasses immediately fog up when I breathe. The little metal strips over the bridge of the nose is entirely useless since it doesn’t have enough strength to mold the mask to the contours of my nose, and I’ve tried all sorts of different ways to position the mask and my glasses to no avail. Do any of you guys have suggestions for how I can fix this with common household items? I don’t have a 3D printer or anything fancy unfortunately 😢

postsData.text:
I am considering options for creating a skin-safe, durable seal for reusable filter-fabric face masks. Has anyone tried medical grade silicone rubber sealants/adhesives/caulks like the kind used to create non-slip bra bands and straps? Note that these create a slight ridge with a smooth surface (no peaks like you'd get with caulk), they bond well to the textile, and they are completely washable. What search terms should I use to source these? Any recommendations for related products?
(Edit: to clarify, I'm looking for the adhesive, not straps, please!)

postsData.text:
For my own production, I tried to optimize the pattern of the #facemask to make it fit so well that there’s no need to touch and straighten it out while wearing. As my #hybridmask might be helpful for others too, I just published the test, instructions, pattern and template: https://www.irisluckhaus.de/hybrid-mask/!
#mask #diymask #showyourmask #masklove #maskpattern #maskmaker #shareamask #wirvsvirus #wearamask #flattenthecurve #stayhome

postsData.text:
A note on acetate/OHP sheets.
Some sheets appear to be dirty when new. This may just be a layer of soluble glue. Try washing with hot water, then wiping down with blue roll.
In the attached photo, the sheet at the bottom of the picture is how some sheets come, the one at the top is after being rinsed with hot water.
Thanks to Benjamin Babik and Joseph Sanchez for the prodding to see if this was the case.

postsData.text: I've done some searching but have been unable to find a face shield design that would accommodate needed protective space around a cochlear implant. We have a medical student who is unable to use any of our hospital's face shield models because it puts too much pressure on the external hardware. Advice/direction would be appreciated. Anyone up for creating a 3D printed version? I'm afraid that's not in my skill set.

postsData.text:
Hey all, here is a jig / stencil I designed to make cutting the curves of face shields easier without specialized equipment. Simply place the jig on a flat surface, slide the transparency sheet into the slot and mark with a marker. Repeat for the next corner, then use scissors to cut. Alternatively you could directly cut if you have a cutting surface and sharp enough tool, although please follow safety precautions.
STL file here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4301086

All $0.50/yd - minimum 10yds

postsData.text:
Two weeks ago I posted this updated video on how to make a face shield from a soda bottle on this site. Thanks to all of you it has been closed captioned in French, Spanish, Malay, Ukranian, Filipino, and Polish! The virus may be peaking in the Europe and America but it is just getting started in the rest of the world – where there is virtually no commercial PPE. The faster it gets to Africa, Latin America, and SE Asia, the more lives it might save. Please share it if you can! It goes without saying that the video is not monetized and has no brands or logos. Just life-saving information.
Thank you!

YOUTUBE.COM
Saving the World From Covid - One Soda Bottle At a Time

postsData.text: Hey. My husband and I came up with a small idea that seemed worth sharing. 😎 This is a flexible wire strip made by braiding garbage bag twist ties together, and then inserted into a simple cloth mask, so it fits a little tighter and more comfortably across our noses.

postsData.text:
Fabric experts: Visiting Nurse Association is in need of masks for patient use while showering to protect the Aides (who will be wearing surgical masks, there are not enough surgical masks for patients).
Would polyester/microfiber or polyester blend be better for this? I have medium weight woven bamboo something (sheets) that feels like microfiber and 60/40 poly cotton woven medium weight on hand.
And of course already cut two different weights/weaves of 100% cotton for inner and outer, but before I sew, thoughts?

postsData.text: I'm going to try this again; it seems like there is lots of focus on masks, but there is a version that is being sewn together by countless people that hospitals are accepting and that needs to continue because that is filling the need. By the time someone 3d prints one, a little old lady has made 20 better masks. When speaking with a person who is administering the tests she told me the masks are very much needed, but they are out of gowns as well. I thought it was important to get the information to the people of this group who could think about a cheap, easy to make effective gown. My first thought is a snuggie sprayed with scotch guard. I'm sure someone will think of something better, but I think it's important to be making things that are actually useful, not just what makes us feel smart..

postsData.text:
AUDIOVISUAL.EC.EUROPA.EU
Coronavirus: snorkling mask becomes ventilator
Marco Monfils shared a link.
April 20 at 2:30 AM ·
Charlotte Valve to convert snorkeling mask into ventilator, 3D print guide available for free on their website, approved by the EU for widespread use, and is already being used in Italy.
I’m not an expert or a doctor or a mechanical engineer. I share this with the best of intentions. If you have any questions, I hope someone else can expand on that for you.
Best of luck to all of us.

postsData.text:
James Myers-Regulinski
April 19 at 9:24 PM ·
Been working with a friend who is a HCP to make an improved ear-guard that can be laser cut. By working with the end user, I learned a ton. I started out with a file I found online, but it was two stiff and too heavy. After several back and froths we found a material and size that works, and added a hair tie. The hair ties allow those with hair to hold their hair together and keep the weight of the ear-guards off of the mask.
postsData.shared_text:

The hair ties allow those with hair to hold their hair together and keep the weight of the ear-guards off of the mask.

postsData.text:
My daughter’s 2nd grade Brownie Girl Scout Troop (in the Girl Scout Council of the Nation’s Capital) has decided to help make masks similar to N-95s to give to nursing home nurses on the front lines. The girls have the supplies to add elastic and padding, but they need masks printed on 3D printers. They haven’t had much success finding 3D printers in our community.
A father of one of the girls in the troop is an anesthesiologist at a local hospital and has been making the masks and using them with great success. He will help work with the girls virtually and all of this will be done by the girls individually in their own homes.
Any ideas of how to get masks printed? We need people willing to print a file we have. Working with
MAKETHEMASKS.COM
Make The Masks
